title: (x) HPs "The Computer is Personal Again" Font - HP PSG (custom, inspired by Jonathan Gray's lettering) {Spire, Stephen}
content:
This font has been bugging me since I first saw the new HP ads. It feels very Tim Burtonesque, but after looking at the cover of "The Nightmare Before Christmas" that definitely isn't the font. It may have been specially created for the campaign, but I really doubt it. Identifont gave a few comparable fonts, but nothing really close and What the Font didn't really help either. Any ideas?  
I zoomed in on the flash to grab this screenshot from:  
http://www.hp.com/personalagain/us/en/index.html

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848im_/http:/typophile.com/files/hp-personalagain_4968.gif)
author: jasongraphix

comments.content: The name of the font embedded in the Flash files is <cite>HP PSG</cite>. I believe this stands for <cite>Hewlett-Packard Personal Systems Group</cite>; the name likely indicates that the font is custom.

These are somewhat similar (albeit even wackier): [Couchlover](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/chank/couchlover/), [Mister Frisky](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/mister-frisky/), [Uncle Stinky](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/t26/uncle-stinky/).

I didn't think to check the Flash for an embedded font. Since the personal systems group is all I come up with when searching for PSG within HPs website, I'm guessing you're right about it being custom face. I like it when novelty fonts are readable and this one certainly is more streamlined than the 3 you posted...although who could resist a font with a name like "Uncle Stinky"? Thanks Spire.

For some other,'neater' looking novelty fonts, Fonthead's [Danette](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fonthead/dannette/) is casual but legible, even if not so bouncy. [Jester](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/drewfonts/jester/) from Drewfonts is kinda goofy, and [MVB Hotsy Totsy](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mvbfonts/mvb-hotsy-totsy/) is wacky but clear.

There are others from Bitstream and House, but some are seen rather often, Like House's Randumhouse.

- Mike Yanega

This is a proprietary font created by FontShop for [Goodby Silverstein](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/gspsf.com/) and HP. The typeface was inspired by the lettering of Jonathan Gray (AKA [Gray 318](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.gray318.com/images/final%20jackets/large%20files/Extremely%20Loud.gif)).
That's interesting and cool. How did you come by this information?

Those fonts are great Mike! ...and thanks for the lead Stephen. I can now sleep at night. Of course those eerie letterforms will still be dancing around in my dreams. After doing a little more searching for Jonathan Gray and the ad campaign I came across [a post about the new ad campaign](http://web.archive.org/web/20150124153848/http:/www.canada.com/nationalpost/news/artslife/story.html?id=e24a508b-ba93-47b5-bc2b-d2ed673e7d46) at canada.com. From the post:
"Noticed by at least a couple of bloggers, the similarities between the ads and the book covers are no coincidence -- well, almost.

The designer behind the font and the original hand happens to be another Jonathan -- Jonathan Gray, or Gray318, as is his moniker -- who, after being commissioned for both of the New York author's best-selling novels, was asked to do something similar for HP.

"We saw the books Jonathan designed and loved the typography for that," said Nancy Reyes of Goodby Silverstein & Partners, a San Francisco advertising agency contracted by HP.

"We weren't too concerned in terms of it looking similar to the book cover," she added. "We were just happy it helped to inspire the campaign."

David Roman, HP's marketing guru, says the design impressed him right away.

"It clicked immediately -- the style of design goes right back to that mid-20th century look that Saul Bass and Paul Rand popularized and I just liked that," he said. "It was a little whimsical, definitely felt personal and we got a lot of positive feedback."
Stephen works for FontShop and knows all.
It's nice, and works well in their catalogs too, but some contextual alternates would have made it extra special. Maybe Goodby Silverstein, HP's agency, is a Quark 6 shop :-(
Some alternates were drawn and part of the font, but most were not used.

The all caps font doesn't work very well with hp's web solution if someone takes the ads literal...
